title: @Morello. So now that worlds is over I'm going to make this thread.
body:
Just a bunch of random quotes I remember.

**Phreak: Aatrox is in a good position right now.
**
0% pick at worlds.

**Ghostcrawler: Jax is a good example of a melee that works.
**
0% pick rate at worlds for the first time... ever. Jokingly highlighted in the last game.

**Patch notes: See you in LCS Shen
**
0% pick rate at worlds. 

**Morello: I think Dr. Mundo is a problematic champion.
**
0% win rate at worlds in what, 8 games? I guess a late game tanky champion (when tanks become useless) who has a single 40% slow as his only CC on a slim skill shot that loses every single lane isn't good for actually winning games, huh?

**Ghostcrawler: We want to fix the Shyvana vs. Mundo slap fight.
**
Shyvana 0% pick rate at worlds. Mundo 0% win rate. Problem solved? 

**Entire Riot: We want Melee to have counterplay.
**
Irelia and Maokai have 0% counterplay. Only melee champions picked consistently at top (and Irelia was dropped like a rock once it became apparent she was dead weight in fast matches as she lost lane to ranged opponents and had to overextend to fight.)

**Entire Riot: Ryze is not overbearing.
**
Ryze is 100% overbearing. 

**Entire Riot: We like where ADCs are at right now.
**
ADCs are 100% dominant right now.

Okay, you have to understand the concept of the current meta. The reason that certain champs like Anivia and Brand aren't picked up in the midlane, despite being seriously powerful, is because they don't fit the meta, composition, or playstyle of the people who play in the LCS. Currently, the meta is dominated by high mobility or long range champions. Anivia and Brand are super stationary champions that don't have the range or spam abilities to compete with champs like Ziggs and Syndra. Champs like Lee Sin are picked up often in the jungle because they can easily snowball a team through the early game. Elise was picked up quite a lot until she got a nerf which I think was needed, but taken too far, because she has high early game damage and extreme pick off potential comparable to Thresh and Morgana. Currently the top lane meta is shifted to favor early game bullies that have extreme late game utility (Maokai and Lulu). Champs like Malphite and Nasus simply cannot survive the early game with the champs that dominate atm. Nasus was picked up a few times this year and won a majority of the time if I'm not mistaken simply because he has late game potential beyond compare (for doing something as simple as last hitting I fucking hate Nasus and will never respect the cane). ADCs need their repositioning tools, which is why Tristana and Lucian are so dominant. True, champs like Kog'Maw, Jinx, and Twitch (pretty much only picked up by cocky af Doublelift) are picked up at certain times too, but usually have the team build around peeling for them since they are super immobile. The biggest problem with Vayne is that she has the weakest early game out of every ADC. Ashe's and Varus' kits needs to be reworked, as their abilities do not support their playstyle; Ashe's passive requires her to not AA, while her Frostshot promotes it, and Varus' Piercing Arrow combined with the worst mobility on any ADC promotes long range poking, but his Blighted Quiver means he has to be constantly in the fight, auto attacking everyone as much as possible. Urgot is absolute garbage the way he is, but if he is buffed he will be overpowered. He should just be removed from the game or have his new playstyle not even come close to resembling his old one. Supports are put into the meta based on either the current meta of ADCs or the current determination of which is broken in terms of stats. Hypercarries are in atm, so Janna and Nami are in.

> The reason that certain champs like Anivia and Brand aren't picked up in the midlane, despite being seriously powerful, is because they don't fit the meta, composition, or playstyle of the people who play in the LCS.

**Brand has not been picked in any LCS game, ever.** This is not because "the meta doesn't fit him", this is because he's inherently unfit for competitive play, period. Long range mages outperform him in poking, toplane bruisers like Rumble and Ryze outperform him in DPS and durability. Also, he's naturally weak against assassins, any sort of mobility and team coordination (same reason why Sejuani isn't a competitve pick).

**There is nothing that Brand can do that the other champions cannot**.

> Currently, the meta is dominated by high mobility or long range champions.

You live in an illusion where "currently" is anything past season one. **Mobility has been the core power creep of LoL for about three years now**, probably since release of Ahri and Fizz - and frankly, the emergence of weekly LCS is what solidified it and showed the world what competitive picks are.

> Anivia and Brand are super stationary champions that don't have the range or spam abilities to compete with champs like Ziggs and Syndra.

News flash: Ziggs' temporary rise to popularity is already gone.

> The biggest problem with Vayne is that she has the weakest early game out of every ADC.

No, that's just how her power curve is supposed to work. Vayne's problem is not the weak early game, it's that her lategame isn't that much stronger than Tristana's or Twitch's, who don't have to pay for it with such weak laning.

*I could argue with your other points, but there were irrelevant to the discussion*

---

BlazingSalvo's point stands: **the competitive champion pool is embarassingly small.** It's 3-4 dominant champions per role, the only thing that changes is what the holy trinity of a given lane is, since the cycle of buffs and nerfs removes a pick or two from time to time.

Due to inherent flaws and the cycle of nerfs half of LoL champs are unfit for competitive play at any given time. The cycle of buffs and nerfs gives an illusion that there are many viable options, when you sum picks from all patches, but that is simply not true.

---

**The problem with LoL is the lack of champion diversity in design**. *All spell effects are too similar to each other*. Swain is so rare because Ryze does pretty much the same (DPS, tankiness, root, heal on R) and doesn't require snowball and heavy AP to be relevant. Vayne was almost nonexistent at Worlds because you can have just as great lategame with Twitch or Tristana and there is nothing particular that Vayne does that those two cannot. Of course if T&T got nerfed to ground, Vayne would be situationally picked again, but that's the problem - champions are too similar, so you just compare them and get the currently strongest one.

Why would you pick [insert mage here] when you have other mages? What can he do that the others cannot? Some conditional CC, burst, DPS - is there anything that makes Brand mid THAT different from Vel'Koz? Lux from Xerath? Mages are too similar, and in result only the select few ones (Orianna, Syndra, Ahri) get picked.

This goes for every role. There are very few champions with abilities distinct enough to make a true difference, doing something no one else can. Good examples are Morgana as support, Thresh, Braum and Yasuo - but the last one was nerfed to ground due to overwhelming annoyance coming from his passive effects. Also, Yasuo was the only carry out of the bunch, with no real competition in the field of being impactful in an original manner.

---

If you want any further proof, look up the picks%bans at Worlds. **Only 50% of champions were picked or banned** over 78 games.

[Here's a post with full statistics](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/491fp4px-worlds-pb-stats-59120-champions-were-picked-in-s4-worlds-17-of-them-made-71-of-picksbans). 17 champions made 70% of picks and bans.

I think it's the lack of changes that people are complaining about. 100+ champions is a very, very charming thing, don't get me wrong; what people don't like is that the viable picks become marginalized while non-viable picks are so to the point that they start costing their team serious ground that the rest of them have to pick up to make back.

Not a deep ranked player or anything but that's my two cents. I'm of the camp that 'if it were truly imbalanced they'd fix it,' but there's no doubt that there's favour in picks, at least where non-viable champs are considered.

So having said all that, I think the expectations-- as angrily as they are submitted-- are toward actually putting their money where their mouths are here and making champs at least equally viable picks, if not equally significant (that's what bans are for, though!).

Two things to consider with that:

A) Some of the champs considered unviable are intentionally put into that state. I wouldn't want to play a League where {{champion:78}} was the staple top lane pick, would you?

B) The competitive meta, especially if so much is on the line, is much more restricted due to players only being able to play so much champions on the highest level continously. On top of it, scrimming only against a limited pool of players with equal limitations on their champion pools tends to reinforce further which champions are seen as viable and which ones are seen as unviable.
And too much of a different champion pool makes you also pretty vulnerable to targeted bans. If the enemy team knows that their enemy, for example, toplaner can't play the "meta" champions too well and instead has his one or two incredibly strong pet picks...which not ban those two away and force him on an uncomfortable champion, making him possibly tilt?

The world championship also showed another different thing - the evolution of a meta on a single, given patch. During NA playoffs, for example, Rumble wasn't even shown once. Became a staple pick the first day. Same with Kayle, Irelia. While other picks lost their significance - Nidalee, Lulu.
Quarterfinals and beyond even had some curveballs thrown in, like Singed, Akali, Kassadin as top lane picks.

I think making exceptions like that, where a champion may not be strictly balanced to the meta's stringent standard, isn't necessarily a bad thing, although it makes it sort of weird to have the option when the game stresses balance so hard otherwise. When they're trying to make the tiniest tweaks for balance, it feels weird that they'd just backpedal on that and make champs who aren't meant to be balanced. And then why have them be allowed picks if they're not balanced? That's going to cause a lot of flak if they get picked. That's not cunning design, that's poor design; at the very least, while they don't have to be the grand meta, champions should never be 'not viable' for at least their standard role. That much, I think, isn't so much to ask... there will always be champions better suited to certain things by virtue of this being, you know, a video game. What there should not be are champions who just cannot be picked. That's poor balance, and again I think that's where complaints are coming from. If they're going to create a champ outside the meta's guidelines, they should at the very least have a point at which they flourish. The way it is now, it feels like some champs just won't see picks because they just don't have the resources that make them useful to a team. Then again, I play ARAM, whose meta is entirely different on its own...

As for the championships, did any of those curveballs manage to take home wins? I don't like to 'preach the meta' as it were, but curveballs-- while nice, and generally fun to watch and play-- don't typically lead to victory in a game with a meta so apparently hard-set as League's. Maybe that's just me, but I find League to have a very strict and unforgiving meta...

The game would not, say, reward itself for having a meta that more forgave builds like Mage Fortune or things like that, but it would benefit pretty greatly from having a more strictly defined standard to which all champions could be held.

As for people losing champs over bans, that's just poor on their part. I'm no ranked player and I'm no pro, but I certainly have more than one role and two champs under my belt. That's just healthy if I'm entering competitive play-- expecting that my one or two picks will never get A) picked, B) banned or C) hard-countered isn't being a good player or meeting expectations, it's holding a dangerously narrow scope on the way the competitive play does and should work.

As for lost or gained significance, Nid might be doing better if she weren't disabled! Hah.

{{champion:78}} is a very old champion, and comes from a time when the design philosophies and core values weren't as developed as they are today. She is one of the hottest candidates for a full rework, now that Sion is out of the way.

Singed won one, lost one. The lost one was not primarily due to him, but due to a generally badly thought-out teamcomp (Singed + Fizz + Twitch = no waveclear and bad siege).

Kassadin won more than he lost, at least. He was picked as a counter to Ryze a lot, as he has the tools to deal with him during laning phase (reduced magic damage) and wants to farm up a lot, too.

The fact of the matter is that there is more that must be done to increase champion diversity than simple buffs and nerfs. It has to go beyond simple number fixes. For any champ to be picked over another based on something other than shear numbers or reliability, they have to bring something specific that other champs don't bring or bring it with a twist. Vi is a good example of this and they actually talked about her a while back. They thought what can we give vi that would make you want to pick her. The answer in there post/blog was the garunteed 1.25 second knockup. You can't dodge her ult, you can't stop it, and you can't out run it (unless you have the best timing on your backs/teleports ever). While you can argue that this isn't fun for the enemy team or what not, it gives you a reason to want to pick her over say lee sin. 

On the side of multiple champs bringing the same thing with a twist, we can compare sejuani and amumu. Both bring excellent aoe initiation for late game team fights. The difference? Amumu has way more damage but is less safe. Sej on the other hand has a greater distance she can initiate from and if she fails it then she can just turn around. You can argue that neither are picked in the pros and thus are a failed design in your mind but sej was very strong after her rework way back because the thing she brought to your team was actually very useful, constant aoe cc at a distance. There are actually a decent number of champs that have unique things they bring to a team but aren't picked in worlds. This is mostly because, at least from what I've seen, in the past riot perceived what was strong or useful about a popular or op champ and nerfed it. The issue was the thing they nerfed was also why that champ was brought along. When they nerfed sej, instead of nerfing her damage, they nerfed her cc, the whole reason you brought her to begin with, making her more similar to other champs. Could you imagine if instead of nerfing oriana's lane harass from autos they nerfed say, they radius on her ult by about 25 or 50? She would have fallen strait off the pick list for the pros. Her follow up cc and team fight set-up is key to her. Not her lane harass. And yet she had lane harass that was above average as well, so they nerfed it. That was a smart nerf, preserving why people would want to pick the champ while removing needless or random strengths they brought along with their selling points. As riot goes forward into improving the game, they will want and need to make balance changes that don't take away from a champs selling point while buffing what they are supposed to be good at. For instance, take the ap poke champs, xerath, lux, ziggs, and sorta syndra (and nid but she is kinda in between a lot of things atm). Why would you pick any of these over another? 

Of the four, xerath and ziggs are muched more focused simply on their range, while syndra and lux bring pick potential from their long range cc. Betwen xerath and ziggs, ziggs used to be picked cause he had better wave clear. Xerath on the other hand brings hard cc and his ult over ziggs, and they have arguably similar wave clear now. If they wanted to distinguish these two more from each other, they could improve zigg's waveclear while taking away from somewhere else, and for xerath focusing more on his ult as it is farely unique, maybe giving another change should it kill someone (with number changes). Not saying either of these changes are a good idea, just giving an example.

Syndra and lux are a bit more complicated which is probably why syndra hasn't been nerfed yet and lux hasn't been buffed other than her passive lately. If you nerf syndras ult which is what most hate about her, you take away from her main strength, picks. Maybe she is too good at it, but it is her thing. Lux on the other hand is just a little too easy to dodge at max range but that is probably a good thing.
